byline.original: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: The Surgeon General of the United States, C. Everett Koop, said today that the recent significant rise in the use of snuff and chewing tobacco could result in more cancer and other illnesses among users. Dr. Koop, at a news conference at which he issued a new report on smokeless tobacco, said that 12 million Americans used such products, many of them after quitting cigarettes. ''It is not a safe substitute for smoking cigarettes,'' Dr. Koop said. ''It can cause cancer and a number of noncancerous oral conditions and can lead to nicotine addiction and dependence.''
